talk.author: did:plc:vk5ub6lpjfhm6uljrtro55wd
talk.utter: You're going to have to explain that.

talk.author: did:plc:73arohju6ylr655svmkfden3
talk.utter: There’s a book called “The High Cost of Free Parking” that is extremely wonk-ish - it reads like a graduate thesis paper. But that’s the thrust of it - having all these places to park our cars is costing us big time in other ways: public transport, dense dev, etc.

talk.author: did:plc:73arohju6ylr655svmkfden3
talk.utter: Yes, but in the land use average, you have 3 spaces per car.

talk.author: did:plc:vk5ub6lpjfhm6uljrtro55wd
talk.utter: Yes and we share two of those with everyone else. One car can only be in one place at any given time.

talk.author: did:plc:vk5ub6lpjfhm6uljrtro55wd
talk.utter: Yes and we share two of those with everyone else. One car can only be in one place at any given time.

talk.author: did:plc:yh4mnskrnoiy3auxzoopoo5j
talk.utter: But for each new person there are three more spaces. Doesn't matter if they are shared, there are still more than can ever be filled by cars by a factor of three.

talk.author: did:plc:vk5ub6lpjfhm6uljrtro55wd
talk.utter: To assert that, you would have to show how many cars there are against how many car parking spaces there are in the UK. Give me some stats.
